It's been quite a while since I wrote a post. 
I was so close in February, but then work got busy, and bam! Corona. 
While Corona has not really gotten in the way of alot of my daily life, other than the isolation getting to me a little,
it did put some extra work burden on me so I did not have a lot of extra time for blogging.
I hope this has changed a little now, and that I can start sharing with you again the fun things I have been learning in R lately. 

In January, I applied for some funding from my department.
With this application, came the need to update my resume, or CV as we call them here in Norway. 
While I was somewhat satisfied with my CV in word (ghasp!), I wanted to be able to use markdown.
Specifically rmarkdown. I knew there had to be a way to make a good CV that would update nicely with new information. 

I did some searching and found the [vitae]{https://github.com/mitchelloharawild/vitae} package, and thought that looked cool.
The package has a good [website](https://pkg.mitchelloharawild.com/vitae/) to get examples and information about it from.
If you decide on making your CV with it, I really recommend having a look.

First things first, downloading the package

```{r, eval = FALSE}
remotes::install_github("mitchelloharawild/vitae")
```

secondly, since vitae requires latex to work, you will likely need to get that installed and working too:
```{r. eval = FALSE}
install.packages('tinytex')
tinytex::install_tinytex()
```

<!-- There are 5 CV tempaltes you can chose from, and switching between to find one you like is pretty easy.  -->
<!-- I personally like the awesomecv template, so we will go with that one for now.  -->

<!-- Choose `awesomecv` to continue with the same example as me. -->

<!-- You will then have an example rmarkdown file open up.  -->

<!-- All depending on what is common to add in your line of work. -->
